This observed correlation of giant-planet frequency and stellar metallicity is most easily understood within the context of the core-accretion model of planet formation (e.g. Pollack et al., 1996). Gas giant planet embryos form beyond the “ice-line” where there is an abundance of solid material to form a planetary core. Those planets that reach the stage of rapid gas accretion while there is still a substantial circumstellar disk can migrate inward through gravitational tidal interactions with the disk. Thus, the correlation of giant planets with stellar metallicity might result naturally from the larger abundance of planet-building material in the disk surrounding a metal-rich star. However, there are two important caveats to this observed relationship. First, the observed distribution has a long tail extending to low-metallicity stars. This means that giant-planets can indeed form at a reduced rate around relatively metal-poor stars, perhaps still by core accretion or possibly by some other planet-building process such as disk gravitational instability (Boss, 2002). An open question remains as to whether there is a low-metallicity threshold for giant-planet formation (Mordasini et al., 2012). Second, this correlation is not seen for super-Earth and Earth-size planets (Buchhave et al., 2012). Thus, the relationship between the elemental abundances of the parent star and the architectures of the planetary systems is not nearly as simple and obvious as was commonly thought several years ago.

coi_names: Conroy, Kyle; Abdul-Masih, Michael; Kochoska, Angela
title: Eclipsing Binary Stars: Indispensable Astrophysical Labs
summary: We present the argument for a continued survey of eclipsing binary and multiple stars by K2 by identifying some of the hot topics that can be tackled by the K2 data. The proposal utilizes the standardized scheme our team used to select targets for all previous GO solicitations. Small program funding is requested to ingest the data into the live catalog hosted at http://keplerEBs.villanova.edu.

coi_names: Hellier, Coel; Southworth, John
title: Hunting for Starspots and TTVs in Known Transiting Exoplanetary Systems
summary: We propose to observe a set of known transiting exoplanet systems during observing Campaigns 17, 18 and 19 in the short-cadence observing mode. The primary goal is to detect starspot occultation events and search for transit-timing variations (TTVs). Secondary goals are to refine system parameters, search for rotational and phase-curve modulations and to search for any potential additional transiting planets. Targets of particular importance are multiplanetary systems HIP 41378 (Vanderburg et al. 2016, C18) and GJ 9827 (Niraula et al. 2017, C19), which are excellent candidates to exhibit measurable TTVs. We also propose to observe an exoplanet candidate 1SWASP J081636.70+162333.1 (EPIC211734699) during C18, whose planetary status may get confirmed with the aid of K2 observations.

coi_names: Wood, Matt; Howell, Steve; Cannizzo, John; Smale, Alan
title: K2 Cycle 6 Observations of Cataclysmic Variables
summary: We propose to continue our highly successful and productive programme to study Cataclysmic Variables using Kepler and K2. Our primary goal is to obtain a better understanding of the physical processes occuring when an accretion disc goes into outburst and how the disc behaves during quiescence. We have identified four CVs in fields 17–19.

coi_names: Aigrain, Suzanne; Jenkins, Jon; Meibom, Soeren; Pinsonneault, Marc; Sandquist, Eric; Soderblom, David; Stello, Dennis; Vanderburg, Andrew
title: Searching for Terrestrial Planets Orbiting Cool Stars and Brown Dwarfs with K2
summary: Our primary goal is to find terrestrial planets orbiting nearby ultra-cool stars and brown dwarfs similar to the TRAPPIST-1 planets. Most proposed targets benefit from spectroscopic observations that will facilitate the characterisation of planets transiting them. None of the Earth-size planets found so far with Kepler will be amenable to detailed characterisation, even with JWST. Our K2 proposed observations represents an opportunity to find rocky planets that could be characterised with JWST or the ELTs. Our second goal focusses on the variability of stars straddling the hydrogen-burning minimum mass. High-precision monitoring of cool stars and brown dwarfs will prove to be particularly useful for understanding the variability nature of these objects in the visible, even if no transit is detected throughout the sample (see Demory et al. 2013b).

coi_names: Demory, B.-O.; Lendl, M.; Hueso, R.; Sanchez-Lavega, A.
title: Multi-Wavelength Characterization of Neptune’s Rotational Brightness Variability
summary: Observing Neptune with K2 over >60 days will offer insight into the planet brightness variability associated with its rotational motion. This knowledge is crucial to understanding various atmospheric phenomena in this ice giant, and provides context for interpreting exoplanet and brown dwarf variability. Ideally, the K2 observations will be accompanied with a simultaneous monitoring campaign from the ground at longer wavelengths. Multi-wavelength data will help constrain the optical properties, horizontal extent and altitude location of the clouds that are ultimately responsible for the brightness variability, thereby fully exploiting the potential of the proposed observations.

coi_names: Carini, Michael; Wiita, Paul
title: Does the Character of Optical Emission from OJ287 and Other Gamma-Ray Blazars Change on Year-Long Timescales?
summary: We propose to determine if the character of optical variability in the binary black hole candidate OJ 287 and 7 more gamma-ray blazars changes on year-long timescales, between our earlier observations and 2018. Just after our first K2 observations of OJ 287, a strong optical outburst occurred which was predicted by modelling of the secondary black hole passing through the accretion disk around the primary black hole. The passage may have changed the variability characteristics of the optical emission from the relativistic jet. Our K2 observations show that blazars can have powerful individual flares that could be caused by a strong individual component in the jet, superimposed on emission that shows fractal variability on all timescales. The slopes of the power spectral densities of their light curves are consistent with relativistic jet turbulence. We also propose to observe five gamma-ray blazars not yet observed by K2.

coi_names: Jackiewicz, Jason
title: Revisiting Main-Sequence Stars Observed in K2 Campaigns 5, 6 and 12
summary: We propose to re-observe main-sequence cluster (M67 and Praesepe) and field stars targeted in our K2 Campaign 5, 6, and 12 proposals on Statistics of Variability that fall on active pixels in K2 Campaigns 18, 17, and 19. A longer time series including data from two campaigns will improve the signal-to-noise in the Fourier transform of the light curve. Furthermore, many targets proposed for C6 and C12 were actually never observed because of target prioritization. We would like to obtain longer time-series baselines to search for changes in the light curves that could indicate an evolving magnetic stellar cycle, a perturbation in a binary orbital period from a companion planet or star, or amplitude, frequency and phase variations resulting from nonlinear phenomena such as mode coupling in pulsating variables. In addition, we propose to observe several brighter candidate gamma Doradus/delta Scuti and hybrid stars identified in earlier campaigns in short cadence, to search for additional modes, study amplitude variability, and remove the frequency ambiguity caused by the 24.5 cycle/day Nyquist frequency reflections present in long-cadence observations. These target variables have high potential for utility of ground-based follow-up observations for asteroseismic modeling.

coi_names: Andrade, Laerte; Pacheco, Eduardo Janot
title: Characterization of Be stars in Kepler K2 fields 17,18 and 19
summary: We propose the photometric characterization of B/Be stars in K2 fields 17, 18 and 19. Classical Be stars are rapid rotators of spectral type B and luminosity class V-III which have an equatorially concentrated circumstellar disk. The disk is fed by discrete mass loss events called outbursts. Rapid rotation alone cannot explain the ejection episodes, and non-radial pulsations (NRP) have been proposed as an explanation. We propose to verify the correlation between the NRP regime and the feeding of the envelope by combining ground-based spectroscopy data with the identification of outbursts and the measurement of small changes in pulsation frequencies with K2 30-min cadence observations. Fourier analysis of photometric data will be performed using a methodology developed by our group for CoRoT and K2 Be stars (Andrade et al., 2017, Neiner et al. 2012, Emilio et al. 2010).

coi_names: Gaensicke, Boris; Marsh, Tom ; Steeghs, Danny
title: Accretion Flows in Interacting Binaries
summary:
Accretion occurs on vast physical scales in the universe. From from the accretion discs which power active galactic nuclei (parsecs), proto-planetary discs around young stellar objects (several AU) and the discs around accreting neutron stars or white dwarfs (few thousand km), the flow of material and angular momentum is governed by the same underlying physical processes. The timescales involved scale as R^2 (where R is the disc radius), so span a vast range. For this reason, the accretion flows around white dwarfs are the ideal laboratories for investigating model disc structure, the effects of accretion rate variations, and accretion flows along magnetic field lines, as the equivalent variations in larger discs cannot be studied in human lifetimes.

Accreting white dwarfs (cataclysmic variables, CVs) display variability on a wide range of timescales, e.g. accretion disc flickering (seconds), white dwarf spin (seconds), eclipses (minutes), white dwarf pulsations (minutes), the orbital period (hours) and precession of the accretion disc (days). The capability of K2 (and the original Kepler mission) to provide uninterrupted, high precision, high cadence photometry over a long baseline is unique, and allows us to sample the variability over a range of timescales that is not possible with ground-based observations. K2 has the additional advantage that it allows us to study a more diverse and representative population of accreting binaries than was possible in the single, fixed Kepler field. The resulting library of high quality light curves from K2 will provide a diverse, representative observational sample from which to investigate disc-based phenomena.

coi_names: Henry, Todd; Clements, Tiffany
title: Monitoring the Closest Stars in K2 Fields 17, 18 and 19
summary:
The fundamentals of stellar astronomy are built upon studies of nearby stars. Because of their proximity and brightness, they provide us with the most reliable answers to questions about stellar populations, multiplicity, structure, and evolution. These nearby stars have accurate optical/infrared photometry in addition to accurate parallaxes, so we know their precise locations on the HR diagram. Using the combination of available parallaxes, photometry, multiplicity, metallicities/ages, variability characteristics, radii, and rotation rates, we will answer a fundamental question in stellar astronomy: What stellar parameter(s) of K and M dwarfs cause the main sequence (MS) to be up to three full magnitudes in width? The RECONS team has initiated programs to understand the relation between the MS width and different stellar parameters discussed above.

We propose to utilize the K2 mission to observe the sample of the nearest K and M dwarfs within 25 pc to accurately determine their rotation rates and amplitudes as two of the key approaches to solve the width problem. In K2 fields 17, 18 and 19, we will observe 18 nearby systems 1 , including seven K dwarfs and eleven M dwarfs. These stars are the closest K and M dwarfs in these three fields other than those stars overlapped with previous fields. Along with previous nearby stars we proposed in K2, the K2 mission has observed 74 nearest K and M dwarfs. Observing these additional 18 stars and as well as others observed in the upcoming tess mission will not only provide crucial data to understand the width of the MS, but has a opportunity to detect any transiting planet sytem similar to TRAPPIST-1. We expect to have the most complete characterization of a set of the nearest K and M stars in all K2 campaigns that have ever been accomplished.

coi_names: Doyle, Lauren; Doyle, Gerry
title: K2 Cycle 6 Observations of Flare Stars
summary: We propose to continue our highly successful and productive programme to study M dwarf flare stars using Kepler and K2. Our primary goal is to obtain a better understanding of the origin of flares from these low mass stars.

coi_names: Hermes, J. J. ; Gansicke, B. T.; Dunlap, B.; Raddi, R.; Gentile Fusillo, N.; Kawaler, S. D.; Clemens, J. C.; Dennihy, E.; Fuchs, J. T.; Bell, K. J.; Montgomery, M. H.; Winget, D. E.
title: K2 Observations of Variable White Dwarfs, Cycle 6
summary: We propose to continue our impactful program of monitoring all visible white dwarf (WD) stars with K2 in Fields 17−19. We request short-cadence observations of known and high-probability pulsating WDs, since the pulsation periods span 100 − 1400 s. Our K2 data will provide unprecedented insight into the interiors of evolved stellar remnants. Additionally, we propose long-cadence observations of hundreds of known and high-probability WDs, many of which are known to be magnetic, in close binaries, or show metal pollution indicating they harbor remnant planetary systems. Overall, our program will more than quintuple the number of rotation rates measured for WDs, both via asteroseismology and spots, constraining the evolution of angular momentum in the final stages of isolated stars. Our observations will provide the capstone for our legacy dataset of WD variability with K2, with progress so far summarized at k2wd.org.

coi_names: Sloan, G. C.; Hermes, J. J.
title: Investigating Galactic Carbon Stars with K2: The Bulge and Halo Population
summary: We propose to observe 32 evolved carbon stars in the long-cadence mode in K2 fields F17, F18, and F19. Stars which have evolved beyond the main sequence can vary on a wide range of timescales, from a few hours to hundreds of days, even in the same star. K2’s 80-day observing window and its 29-minute sample rate make it ideal for investigating these variations. However, most previous Kepler and K2 observations of evolved stars have concentrated on oxygen-rich samples [e.g., 1, 2], probably because they outnumber the carbon stars, at least in the Milky Way. Carbon stars, though, may be responsible for at least half the dust returned to the Galactic interstellar medium (ISM) [e.g., 10, 5], and may even dominate dust production in the early Universe [e.g., 21, 8]. To investigate this important population, we recently acquired K2 observations of evolved carbon stars. While we are still analyzing those data, we are, indeed, finding variations on the order of a few hours to tens of days. However, those stars were primarily in the Galactic plane and suffer from crowding effects. The next set of K2 fields, most likely the last, contain more than thirty known carbon stars that are toward the bulge and halo. With these new data, we will significantly expand the sample of this important population with high quality K2 data. With a robust sample of carbon stars, we can also test asteroseismologic techniques and models that have been developed for oxygen-rich stars [e.g., 4], potentially determining parameters like mass, radius, and surface gravity, independent of their unknown distances.

pi_institution: Leibniz Institut für Astrophysik Potsdam AIP
coi_names: Cristina, Chiappini; Miglio, Andrea; Bossini, Diego; Davies, Guy; Anders, Friedrich; Mosser, Benoit
title: Towards Precise Ages for Metal Poor Stars
summary: Age and mass determinations for metal-poor halo stars are key information helping constraining the chemical enrichment of the early phases of the Galaxy assembly as well as the nature of the first stellar generations. To date, very few metal-poor stars have an age determination, but the situation is bound to change thanks to the availability of seismic constrains. Here we aim at measuring solar-like oscillations for 14 metal-poor giant stars, selected from RAVE survey and literature. Ages will be determined by combining seismic information with the atmospheric parameters and chemical abundances measured using spectroscopy.

title: Rapid Optical Variability in Infrared and Optically Bright blazars
summary: Blazars are extreme examples of the Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) phenomena. The scientific goals of this proposal are to use K2’s unique capabilities to determine flare timescales and frequency, which set limits to the size of the emitting region, and determine the shape of the power spectral density (PSD), which yields characteristic variability timescales, describes the underlying emission process, and constrains characteristic emitting region sizes in blazars. Unique to this cycle is the fact that the field of view for F16 and F6 overlap with 12 sources in common, F18 and F16 overlap with 8 sources in common (including the bright and highly variable source OJ 287) and F19 and F12 overlap with 6 sources in common This allows the experiment to be repeated for a total of 26 sources. Ground based contemporaneous monitoring of the sample sources will occur in order to validate the variability detected by K2 in these sources the importance of which has been shown by by Mushotzky et al. (2011), Carini & Ryle (2012) & Wherle, Carini & Wiita (2017)

coi_names: Sestovic, M.; Grimm, S.; Gillon, M.; Agol, E.; Jehin, E.; Van Grootel, V.; Burgasser, A.; Lederer, S.; Turbet, M.; Luger, R.; Ingalls, J.; de Wit, J. ; Kruse, E.; Holdsworth, D.
title: Dynamical Masses and Additional Companions in the TRAPPIST-1 System, Part II
summary: TRAPPIST-1 (Gillon et al. 2017) hosts some of the most favourable Earth-size exoplanets amenable to a detailed characterisation of their atmospheres with current and future facilities such as JWST. This proposal is a continuation of our efforts to characterise the dynamics of TRAPPIST-1’s seven-planet resonant chain. We will improve current masses and densities of all planets thanks to the extended time-baseline of the proposed K2 Campaign 19 observations. The new transit timings will help to lift existing degeneracies and tighten our knowledge of the bulk interiors of the seven planets. The proposal will also explore the presence of additional companions through dynamical interactions with the known planets. Our proposal fits in a multidisciplinary effort to characterise the formation and evolution of the TRAPPIST-1 system and to prepare the transition to JWST.

coi_names: Farihi, Jay; Hermes, J. J.
title: Phoenix From The Ashes: Coronal Activity In Old Dwarf Stars
summary: Carbon (giant) stars are identified by the presence of molecular carbon (C2) absorption bands in their optical spectra indicating that the C/O ratio has been tipped above unity, owing to core dredge-up of triple-α burning products. Intriguingly, a similar carbon enhancement is observed in dwarf stars, a strong indication of extrinsic carbon pollution. The prototype dwarf carbon (dC) star (G77-61; Dahn et al. 1977) exhibits clear halo kinematics, and is extremely metal poor ([Fe/H] = −4.03; Plez & Cohen 2005). This star is also a single lined spectroscopic binary, with a presumably cold white dwarf secondary (Dearborn et al. 1986). These data support efficient binary mass transfer, from a carbon-rich giant onto a solar-type main-sequence star. Among the growing number of dC stars discovered in the SDSS, there are more than a dozen that exhibit Hα emission, suggesting these stars are spun up due to mass transfer and subsequent accretion. We propose to observe all dC stars in the upcoming K2 campaign fields to measure and constrain rotation periods and flares. The overall goal is to constrain mass and angular momentum transfer, and our findings will be compared with established age-rotation-activity relations for isolated main-sequence stars.

coi_names: Telting, John; Baran, Andrzej S; Jeffery, Christopher Simon; Ostensen, Roy H.
title: Demystifying the extreme horizontal branch stars using K2 seismology
summary:
The stars that are spectroscopically classified as subdwarf B (sdB) stars are found in the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram between the main sequence and the white dwarf cooling track. They are compact stars and the majority are located on the blue extension of the horizontal branch, earning them the designation extreme horizontal branch (EHB) stars. They are helium burning cores of low-mass stars (<2.0 solar masses) that ignited helium through the core-helium flash when their cores reached the required mass of 0.47 solar mass. They have effective temperatures between 20000 and 40000K and the surface gravities (in logarithmic cgs units) between 5.0 and 6.0. (Heber 2016). For the envelope to become this thin, some process, which is still under investigation, must have stripped off the majority of the mass during or immediately after the first red-giant branch stage. Subdwarf B stars are idealized laboratories for studying the deep interiors of helium burning red giants, and can provide important constraints on their evolution.

Kilkenny et al. (1997) discovered the first pulsating sdB (sdBV) star and this has opened the way to study their interiors using asteroseismology. Charpinet et al. (1997) calculated theoretical models of sdBV stars and explained the flux variations as pressure (p) modes driven by the kappa-mechanism, which works on iron opacities, the so-called Z-bump. When sdBV stars were discovered, a monitoring of their flux variation was limited to ground-based observations. Therefore, observations with decent coverage were limited to those pulsators that were fairly bright and showed relatively high pulsation amplitudes and short periods. These objects could be reliably observed with relatively small telescopes so that they could be observed for durations sufficient to explore the detailed structure of the pulsations. The amplitude spectra of ground based data showed many peaks associated with pulsation modes. However, in spite of dedicated efforts on many targets, features that could allow mode identification were usually not found.

The sdBV stars were high-priority targets observed by the Kepler spacecraft from the onset. During the original mission (K1), a survey of ~100 compact pulsator candidates was undertaken (Østensen 2010, 2011), and almost 20 such objects were discovered. They were monitored for up to 3.5 years, which helped us to obtain an exceptionally low noise level and unprecedented frequency resolution, leading to discoveries of many rotationally split multiplets and reliable asymptotic period spacings. These two features are very useful in mode identification, owing to which the application of asteroseismology should be easier than in case of sdBV stars observed from the ground. During the K2 mission, thus far, we have found another 29 sdBV stars. The total sample of stars observed from space is now comparable with the one observed from the ground, though, the superior precision of the former is making them much more relevant for modeling purposes. We expect to find/observe more sdBV stars during the remaining Campaigns 17-19 of K2 mission.

coi_names: Skinner, Julie N.; Sagear, Sheila
title: Activity And Planets At The Bottom Of The Main Sequence
summary: We propose to continue our program using K2 to measure rotational periods, flare rates and rocky planet occurrence at the M/L transition by observing a total of 531 ultracool dwarfs with K2 in Cycle 6 in long-cadence mode. The M/L transition is at the very bottom of the main sequence, where stars and young brown dwarfs overlap on the HR diagram. Such ultracool dwarfs are numerous throughout the galaxy, yet many of their properties are unknown due to their intrinsic faintness. K2’s large aperture and photometric precision offer us the opportunity to study both stellar activity and planet occurrence around these interesting objects.

coi_names: Ryan, Austin; Redfield, Seth; Endl, Michael; Cauley, P. Wilson
title: Searching For Extended Exoplanetary Atmospheres Around Active Stars
summary: We propose to observe a sample of chromospherically active stars in the K2 Campaign 17, 18, and 19 fields to expand upon a funded Cycle 3 program covering Campaign fields 8 and 10 (15-K2GO3 2-0040). Additional targets from follow-up proposals for this program were selected in Cycles 4 and 5 (Fields 11–15 as of this writing, Field 16 pending) for a total of 417 targets. The goal in observing these stars is to (1) search for planets around active stars that may show significant star-planet interaction (SPI) and be good transmission spectroscopy folllow-up candidates and (2) expand the active number of stars with detailed light curves to study their variability.

coi_names: Omohundro, Mark; Becker, Juliette; Kristiansen, Martti H.; Schmitt, Al; Schwengeler, Hans; Terentev, Ivan; Venner, Alexander
title: Re-observing   Known   Exoplanets   and   Candidates   from   Previous   K2   Campaigns
summary: We propose both long cadence (LC) and short cadence (SC) observations of 214 (84 in SC) previously identified planet candidate hosts and confirmed planet hosts from previous K2 fields in C17-19. All three fields overlap with previous K2 fields, providing a rare opportunity for K2 to obtain follow-up observations of many previously identified candidates with both LC and SC. This opens up new science opportunities and enhances existing ones. We will​ ​ leverage​ ​ longer​ ​ time​ ​ baselines​ ​ and​ ​ higher​ ​ cadence​ ​ to detect​ ​ planets​ ​ with​ ​ longer​ ​ periods​ ​ than​ ​ was​ ​ possible​ ​ in​ ​ 80​ ​ days​ ​ of​ ​ observations; improve​ ​ measurements​ ​ of​ ​ transit​ ​ parameters​​ and​ ​ transit​ ​ ephemerides; measure​ ​ planet​ ​ masses​ ​ and​ ​ probe​ ​ system​ ​ architectures​ ​ via​ ​ transit​ ​ timing​ ​ variations; measure​ ​ spin/orbit​ ​ alignment​ ​ with​ ​ starspot​ ​ crossing​ ​ events; characterize​ ​ host​ ​ stars​ ​ by​ ​ detecting​ ​ their​ ​ seismic​ ​ oscillations; determine​ ​ asteroseismic​ ​ properties​ ​ of​ ​ the​ ​ host​ ​ stars.

title: K2’s Keys to the Solar System: Studying Potential Volatile Rich Objects
summary: Recent studies of Solar System dynamics, motivated in part by the discovery of hot Jupiter exoplanets, suggest that giant planet migration has shaped the dynamics of our Solar System. Key predictions resulting from these dynamical models include a common source for inner solar system Hilda group and Trojan asteroids and Scattered Kuiper Belt objects (KBOs) and comet nuclei. While the colors of bodies in these four populations are similar, definitively linking these objects to the same source reservoir is difficult given a lack of surface spectral features and the very different solar radiation environment in each region. To test models these objects share a common origin, physical characterization such as variability studies with Kepler are required to determining the binary fraction and densities for a large sample of comets, Hildas and Trojans.

coi_names: Barstow, Martin A.; Belardi, Claudia; Braker, Ian P.; Holberg, Jay
title: Eclipses, Transits And Variability Of White Dwarf Stars With Kepler
summary: White dwarfs (WDs) teach us about the final evolutionary stages of stars and their planetary systems, during which a significant fraction of the stellar envelope is lost. Previously, the majority of WDs were assumed to be photometrically stable and often used as calibration standards. Kepler has now shown that 30 − 50% of WDs are in fact variable. Such behaviour can reveal the presence of hitherto unseen brown dwarf (BD), degenerate, and potentially planetary companions, surface magnetic star-spots, evidence for accretion, and provide WD rotation rates.

coi_names: Gaudi, B. Scott; Cochran, William D.; Shporer, Avi; Grziwa, Sascha; Eigmueller, Philipp
title: Probing The Planetary Population Of High-Mass Stars (K2-GO6)
summary: We propose to observe a sample of main sequence A and early F stars with K2 in order to search for planets, which we will confirm using Doppler tomography and analysis of the orbital phase curve. This will expand the number of known planets in this poorly-explored region of parameter space.

coi_names: Muller, Thomas; Kiss, Csaba; Pal, Andras; Szakats, Robert
title: Main Belt Asteroid Studies With Kepler
summary: We propose to continue Kepler observations of main belt asteroids with long rotation periods and/or small amplitudes to decrease selection effects persistent in physical studies of asteroids, by taking advantage of Kepler possibility for continuous observations lasting for many days.

coi_names: Preston, Heather
title: Solar Analogs: Rotation, Activity, Gyrochronology
summary: This project has two mutually supportive goals. First, we will extract light curves and measure rotation periods and photometric activity levels for all bright (V < 10) solar analogs in the C17, C18, and C19 fields, a total of 242 targets. Only long-cadence (30-minute) observations are requred. This work expands on our existing Kepler and K2 analysis, and the use of new fields will allow us to compare different stellar populations and to provide a growing sample of test data for the study of stellar activity, rotation, and gyrochronology (Barnes 2003, Barnes 2007, Garcia et al. 2014, Barnes et al. 2016, Angus et al. 2015). Second, we will make use of our large and growing database of Kepler and K2 light curves to search for the best solar twin candidates and Maunder minimum candidates on which we can perform ground-based and space-based (Chandra, HST) follow-up observations. We have have proposed related versions of this project since K2 Campaign 4 and have been allocated nearly 2000 long-cadence targets but no funding.

coi_names: Plachy, Emese; Molnar, Laszlo; Juhasz, Aron L.; Kolenberg, Katrien
title: The K2 RR Lyrae and Cepheid Survey
summary: Low amplitude variations induced by new dynamical phenomena were found in space photometric observations in classical pulsating stars (period doubling, non-radial modes in RRc and RRd stars, modulated RRd stars, multiple modulations in RR Lyrae stars, period jitter in Cepheids). In this proposal, we continue our K2 RR Lyrae and Cepheid survey which has a threefold aim: (1) to study the newly found dynamical phenomena, (2) to analyze their statistical properties, and (3) to create a reference catalog with textbook quality light curves. These goals can be accomplished only with high precision K2 observations. Our final list covering all the K2 fields will comprise over 4000 RR Lyrae stars and hundreds of Cepheids, a lasting legacy for decades to come.

coi_names: Jackiewicz, Jason; Guzik, Joyce
title: Stellar Pulsations in Eclipsing-Binary Systems
summary: We propose to test asteroseismic scaling relations and shed light on the unexplained main-sequence hybrid puslators, taking advantage of additional constraints from bright binaries including one or more pulsators.

coi_names: Basu, Sarbani; Chaplin, William J.; White, Timothy R.; Huber, Daniel; Aguirre, Victor Silva; Davies, Guy R.; Latham, David W.; Casagrande, Luca; Grundahl, Frank
title: Asteroseismology Of Solar-Type Stars With K2
summary: The aim of this proposal is to perform an asteroseismic study of bright solar-type stars, including cool main-sequence (MS) dwarfs and sub-giants, residing in the solar neighbourhood. This will be achieved using short-cadence (SC) data collected during K2 Campaigns 17, 18, and 19 (C17-19). In addition to field stars we propose observations of members of the clusters M44 and M67, as well as several confirmed and candidate exoplanet host stars, of which some have K2 observations from earlier campaigns.

coi_names: Cauley, P. Wilson; Farihi, Jay; Gaensicke, Boris; Veras, Dimitri
title: A Search For Transiting Objects Orbiting White Dwarf Stars
summary: Given their small size, approximately the size of a terrestrial planet, white dwarf stars present an intriguing sample to monitor for transiting objects. Several researchers have explored the possibility of detecting very small objects, even down to exoasteroids, around white dwarf stars (e.g., Di Stefano et al. 2010, Agol 2011, Loeb & Maoz 2013, Fulton et al. 2015). The detection of the first transit of planetary objects orbiting a white dwarf came in the first campaign of K2 (Vanderburg et al. 2015), and likely signals just the beginning of new detections of an exciting class of planetary systems. Follow-up photometry (Croll et al. 2015, Gaensicke et al. 2016) and spectroscopy (Xu et al. 2016) show that the system is dynamic and changing on short (days to weeks) timescales. Our team is involved in the immediate follow-up, both photometrically (Gaensicke et al. 2016) and spectroscopically (Redfield et al. 2016, see Fig. 1). The transit of an Earth-sized planet would cause a full eclipse of the host star, and therefore would be easy to detect. However, the transits are very short, on the order of seconds to minutes. This makes them good targets for a continuous, high-precision, short cadence K2 program.

coi_names: Cauley, P. Wilson; Niraula, Prajwal
title: Monitoring Targets Within 100 Parsecs
summary: Temporal monitoring of stars within 100 parsecs provides an opportunity to search for close planetary systems that are optimal for follow-up studies, as well as evaluate the stellar properties that are critical to the evolution of planetary atmospheres. We are moving into an era in which our sample of terrestrial exoplanets will continue to grow with dedicated ground and space-based surveys (e.g., K2 and the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite [TESS]). A major scientific endeavor related to this population of planets will be the evaluation of habitability and a search for biosignatures. It is precisely these nearest systems that our measurements of their atmospheres will be the most sensitive and the question of habitability will be examined in greatest detail in the decades to come. An excellent example is the recent discovery of a three super-Earth system around a bright (V = 10.1 mag) star, GJ9827 (see Fig. 1). This star was in our target list for this program in Campaign 12. Our team reported the discovery in Niraula et al. (2017) and it was independently reported in Rodriguez et al. (2017). This planetary system is the nearest system ever discovered by Kepler or K2. It, and other nearby planetary systems, will be intensively studied in the years to come.

coi_names: Poppenhaeger, Katja; Watson, Christopher A.; Heller, Rene
title: Searching For Exoplanets In Transit Visibility Zones Of The Solar System
summary: We propose to observe stars located in the transit visibility zones of the solar system planets as long-cadence targets in order to detect exoplanets. Transit visibility zones are locations in the sky from where the transits of at least one solar system planet are observable. Exoplanetary systems in such regions are potential targets for future extraterrestrial communication attempts. In our requested sample of 732 stars, we expect to find roughly 4 transiting exoplanets located in the stellar habitable zone. This estimate is based on an occurrence rate of 0.5 planets per star (Dressing, Charbonneau, 2015; Petigura et al., 2013) and an average geometric transit probability of 1% for a planet orbiting in the centre of the habitable zone. The total number of planet candidates from this sample will be much greater.

coi_names: Molnar, Laszlo; Kiss, Csaba; Hanyecz, Otto; Muller, Thomas
title: K2’s Final Look Beyond Neptune
summary: Here we propose to observe 10 + 7 + 14 trans-Neptunian objects (TNOs) and centaurs in order to recover their basic physical properties such as rotational periods, brightness variation amplitudes and the phase angle dependence of the observed flux.

coi_names: Luhn, Jacob K.; Wright, Jason T.
title: Developing Predictors Of Radial Velocity Jitter From K2 Light Curves
summary: We propose to use the high-precision light curves from the K2 mission with archival radial velocity (RV) jitter and activity measurements to (1) develop an empirical relation between RV jitter and light curve variations, following the methodology developed by Bastien et al. (2014) and (2) determine the dependency of the relation on age, spectral type, and magnetic activity. These relations will prove useful for RV follow-up of existing transiting exoplanet candidates. We will use them to identify targets that have low levels of RV jitter and use them to uncover the physical causes of RV jitter, which will help optimize the use of upcoming RV facilities like NASA’s NEID spectrograph.

coi_names: Vogeley, Michael; Moreno, Jackie; Kasliwal, Vishal
title: Quasar Variability As A Function Of Accretion Rate
summary: We seek to constrain models of quasar accretion disks by exploring differences in the variability properties of high and low accretion rate quasars. With K2 data we can distinguish between the two most common statistical models of quasar variability: a damped harmonic oscillator and a damped random walk. We will create a public legacy database of light curves and variability properties for up to 3268 luminous quasars with a broad range of redshifts and accretion rates. All of these objects have prior K2 epochs and SDSS photometry, providing a crucial legacy database for variability investigations of quasars. 784 are on SDSS “Stripe 82” region where long-term variability information is already available for up to 100 epochs over an 8 year period. Our results will help optimize the cadence of future observations by time domain surveys. This research team combines expertise in time series analysis, variability studies of AGN, statistical analysis of large surveys, multi-wavelength observations of quasars and has demonstrated experience working with both Kepler data (Kasliwal et al., 2015a,b) and quasar variability in general (Peters et al., 2015).

coi_names: Ryan, E.; Porter, S.; Ragozzine, D.; Thirouin, A.
title: Evolution of Spin States in Transneptunian Binaries
summary: We propose long cadence K2 observations of 19 transneptunian binary and candidate binary systems to constrain the rotation states of their component bodies. This information is crucial to understanding their formation environment in the protoplanetary nebula as well as their subsequent evolution. K2’s ability to observe continuously is key to teasing apart the rotational modulations of both bodies if they are different, or being able to determine that they are not, in cases where they have become tidally locked like Pluto and Charon.

title: A continued search for exoplanets and close stellar/substellar companions in the local halo population for K2 campaigns 17-18-19
summary: The physical properties of low-mass, halo stars, which are both very old and very metal-poor, remains poorly characterized due to the paucity of eclipsing systems that have been identified in this population. In addition, few (if any) exoplanet transits have been confirmed in this population. These stars can however be identified as high as high-velocity objects, based on selection in a reduced proper motion diagram, and several thousands have been monitored in K2 so far, leading to the identification of at least 4 eclipsing systems (see below). A search of the SUPERBLINK proper motion catalog now identifies 2,441 additional high-velocity stars that are likely members of the Galactic halo, which will be visible in K2 campaigns C17-C18-C19, and which have also not been targeted in previous campaigns. We propose to target all those stars with K2 to continue our search for eclipsing systems, as well as for the potential identification of exoplanet transits. Based on previous success rates, we expect to find a few (1-3) additional eclipsing systems within this final subset of local galactic halo stars for K2.

coi_names: Kristiansen, Martti Holst; Armstrong, David
title: Second Time Around - Searching For The Second Signals Of Long-Period K2 Planets & Eclipsing Binaries
summary: K2 has provided many well-characterised exoplanets & binary stars orbiting around bright stars with periods less than ∼50 days. However, the high-precision photometry of K2 also means that longer-period objects are detectable from a single transit or eclipse. We propose to reobserve 65 targets that were previously studied with K2 and which our search has detected evidence for a long-period planetary or binary companion. The reobservation of transits or eclipses will allow the period to be determined, enabling long-period transiting plants to be validated or confirmed with K2 for the first time. Such worlds, especially around the bright stellar sample that K2 provides, will improve constraints on the occurrence, structure and orbit of warm and cool exoplanets, which may even include habitable-zone terrestrial planets.

coi_names: Petigura, Erik; Christiansen, Jessie; Isaacson, Howard; Sinukoff, Evan; Crossfield, Ian; Schlieder, Josh; Benneke, Bjoern; Ciardi, David
title: Small Planets and Their Occurrence in K2 Campaigns 17-19
summary: We propose large, magnitude-limited samples of FGKM dwarfs for long-cadence K2 observations. These samples will enable planet searches and complement our magnitude-limited samples in previous Campaigns. As with the previous fields, our team will construct robust catalogs of planets buttressed by detailed examinations of light curves, high-resolution spectroscopy, and adaptive optics imaging. We emphasize specifically in this proposal stars that were observed in previous K2 Campaigns that can be observed again in Campaigns 17–19. Second visits for these stars will increase our search sensitivity, particularly for longer-period planets, and enable comparisons of planet occurrence in different regions of the Milky Way.

pi_institution: Institute for Astronomy, University of Hawaii
coi_names: Gaidos, Eric; Howard, Andrew; Lopez, Eric
title: Giants Orbiting Giants: Characterizing Giant Planets Around Evolved Stars With K2
summary: Most current exoplanet transit surveys target cool dwarfs, leaving planets orbiting evolved stars largely unexplored. Studies of low-luminosity red-giant branch (LLRGB) stars can combine asteroseismology and transit observations to precisely characterize both host stars and planets. We exploit this to investigate how stellar incident flux can inflate close-in gas-giant planets (“hot Jupiters”), a major outstanding question in exoplanet science. We have found evidence that direct deposition of stellar energy may be responsible for the inflation of two giant planets discovered in our K2 survey of LLRGB stars (Grunblatt et al. 2016, 2017), but more systems are required to confirm this intriguing result. We propose to continue our survey in C17-C19 to detect additional planets and collect more data on planets and candidates discovered in earlier campaigns.

pi_institution: Institute for Astronomy, University of Hawaii
coi_names: White, Timothy; Pope, Ben; Aerts, Conny; Bedding, Tim; Boyajian, Tabetha; Creevey, Orlagh
title: Asteroseismology Of The Brightest K2 Stars
summary: The most powerful tests of stellar structure and evolution come from the brightest stars in the night sky, for which complementary observational techniques can be combined. So far, stars brighter than Kp ∼ 8 mag were rarely observed with Kepler/K2 due to the large number of pixels required to capture the saturated pixel columns. Here, we propose K2 observations of the brightest stars in C17-C19 using a novel technique that uses a small number of unsaturated pixels for stars with V < 6 mag. Photometry of these targets will allow unprecedented tests of asteroseismic scaling relations, which will pave the way for the success of the K2 Galactic Archeology Program. It will also provide insights into poorly understood internal processes of intermediate-mass stars, such as convective core overshooting. Our observations will provide a legacy catalog of K2 light curves for the brightest and most valuable stars in the ecliptic plane.

coi_names: Quintana, Elisa; Schlieder, Joshua; Davenport, James
title: Cool Star Flares Through Time
summary: Cool stars are abundant and frequently host small planets. In the coming decade, efforts to detect and characterize rocky planets will focus on M-dwarfs. However, these stars are known to be highly magnetically active, thus planets they host are subjected to significantly more radiation than we experience from the Sun; just how much this affects their habitability is unsettled. We are undertaking an ambitious multi-year, multi-instrument campaign to monitor M-dwarfs with ages from 10 Myr to 10 Gyr at X-ray, UV, optical, and radio wavelengths. The combined data will provide a complete picture of M dwarf activity, enabling us to identify environments conducive to habitable worlds. This proposal is to provide high cadence, long-baseline monitoring of young and field M-dwarfs from K2. The K2 data will reveal the frequency of low amplitude, short duration events. Furthermore, by selecting targets that have been observed previously, we will measure changes in activity on time-scales of years.

coi_names: Coulter; Drout; Fox; Jha; Kilpatrick; Piro; Rest; Riess; Scolnic; Shappee
title: Multi-Observatory Monitoring of K2 Supernovae
summary:
The K2 Supernova Cosmology Experiment will observe >∼ 10 galaxies with 30-minute cadence to discover and follow supernova (SN) candidates. We have selected 9,437 "ideal" galaxies that will fall on silicon for Campaigns 17/19. This is in addition to our ∼6000 galaxies selected for Campaign 16. K2 should detect 6–21 Type Ia SNe (SNe Ia) in this sample during Cycle 6 (90% confidence using current SN rates [6], Poisson statistics, and including systematic uncertainties).

To take full advantage of the K2 SN Cosmology Experiment, we will photometrically follow all SN candidates with four telescopes: the 1.8-m Pan-STARRS (PS1), 1.5-m RATIR, 1-m Nickel and 1-m Swope. In combination, we will observe every K2 SN in 13 bands (uBVgrRiIzyYJH). The different sites/longitudes allow for improved cadence and mitigate against poor weather and telescope/instrument problems at a single site. Additionally, PS1 and the Swope telescope are particularly well-calibrated [12, 14, 19]. PS1 was used to discover ∼5000 high-z SNe and is currently used for the low-z Foundation survey (Foley et al., submitted). The Swope telescope was used for the Carnegie SN Project [3], which has also observed hundreds of SNe [5]. Observations on these well-calibrated systems will directly link the K2 SNe to thousands of other SNe observed on these systems.

Our program has 3 main goals. 1: we will provide the best distances to SNe Ia. This will allow us to improve K2 measurements of important physical parameters such as radii of the progenitor stars and to look for subtle correlations between K2 light curves and Hubble residuals. 2: we will use the K2 SNe Ia as a “Rosetta” sample, anchored to the PS1 system. As the K2 SNe will be observed by many telescopes, it is a rare opportunity to cross-calibrate all telescopes using SNe themselves. 3: we will monitor all newly discovered SNe at high cadence in multiple bands. Our 13 filters span effective wavelengths of 350–1635 nm. Our filtered observations at these early times will provide important color information to complement the K2 light curves.

coi_names: Buzasi, Derek; Davenport, James; Oswalt, Terry
title: Gyrochronology and Magnetic Activity in Wide Binaries with K2
summary:
Precise ages for field stars are a critical fundamental parameter for advancing our knowledge of the Milky Way’s formation history. Likewise, understanding exoplanetary formation and habitability depends on accurate stellar ages. Stars lose angular momentum as they age, causing their rotation rates to slow over time (Skumanich 1972). Assuming stars are born with an initial distribution of rotation periods and gradually spin down, this angular momentum evolution provides a useful clock – a technique known as "gyrochronology". As the stars spin down the internal magnetic dynamo also diminishes; this process has been dubbed "magnetochronology". As rotation slows, decreased magnetic activity results in smaller starspot filling factors, lower levels of X-ray and UV emission, and decreased flare rates. Flares have been recently shown to decline as stars spin down. However, ~12% of flaring wide binaries in Kepler show differing levels of flare activity between components (Clarke & Davenport in Prep).

While stellar rotation is reliably recovered for many stars with Kepler/K2 (Aigrain et al. 2015), the accuracy of ages determined from these periods is debated, with typical uncertainties of ~1 Gyr. Furthermore, prescriptions for gyrochronology relations have been devised using a variety of calibrations, ranging from young open clusters at fixed ages (e.g. Barnes 2010, Meibom et al. 2011), to asteroseismology-based ages for solar mass stars (e.g. Angus 2015). None of these models yield reliable or uniform age estimates for stars at all ages and masses. Widely separated common proper motion binary stars provide a unique benchmark for testing these competing gyrochronology relations across all masses and ages, and for potentially creating an independent spin-down calibration. The range of rotation rates, ages and masses among the wide binaries selected for our study can populate the entire rotation-mass-age surface and help resolve the current disagreement between rotation and asteroseismology ages (cf. García et al. 2014; Barnes et al. 2016; dos Santos et al. 2016; Gonzales 2016; van Saders et al. 2016).

We are proposing for long cadence observations of ~180 wide binary systems (total 369 stars) with K2 Campaign 17, 18, and 19. Our study has three objectives: 1. Calibrate the stellar rotation–age paradigm using wide main sequence (MS) binaries, where components are coeval and have evolved independently; and 2. Quantify the flaring rate among the MS+MS binaries as a function of age. This dataset will build on our previous successful proposal for total ~1060 binaries from Campaign 5, 14, 15, as well as the ~200 systems in the original Kepler field. In total, we hope to create a publicly available catalog of wide binary systems at a range of masses and ages to calibrate evolution of the age-rotation–activity relation.

title: K2 Ages of Thick-Disk K Dwarfs
summary: The scientific goal of this proposal is to determine the diversity in age among K dwarfs located ~1kpc above the Galactic plane. Youthful members are revealed from semi-periodic brightness variations of up to 1% caused by sunspots rotating across the stellar disk. In open clusters aged 1 Gyr or less, single GK dwarfs have rotational periods of ≥10 days, but in open clusters several Gyr old, their periods exceed 20 days. The proposed K2 light curves are for field K dwarfs with Kepler magnitudes 16.5/17.0 < Kp < 18.6 in C17 and C19, both at galactic latitude b ~ 60°. They will show to what extent binaries and young stars are present among the main-sequence stars at the above heights, constraining scenarios of the formation of the disk populations of the Galaxy.

coi_names: Paudel, Rishi; Mullan, Dermott; Burgasser, Adam; Schmidt, Sarah; Williams, Peter K. G.; Berger, Edo
title: K2 Ultracool Dwarfs: The Final Survey
summary: Kepler K2 has proven to be a powerful tool to learn about substellar atmospheres that are not irradiated by a hot primary. “Ultracool” dwarfs, with spectral types M7-M9, L, T and Y, show evidence of condensate cloud formation, a process also important in extrasolar planets. Almost all are rapid rotators and apparently generate fields of many kG (Reiners & Christensen, 2010; Berdyugina et al., 2017). These dwarfs, with T e↵ <⇠ 2700K, can be either very-low-mass hydrogen-burning stars (at types M to L4) or degenerate brown dwarfs. The broad Kepler filter allows a few “bright” ultracool dwarfs to be observed in each Kepler K2 field and numerous fainter dwarfs. Each K2 campaign field includes a random sampling of nearby field dwarfs, so that over the life of the mission, we built up a large sample. Our program is aimed at three main science areas: (1) Weather and rotation in substellar atmospheres, (2) Planetary transits, and (3) White light flares.

coi_names: Boyajian, Tabetha; Fischer, Debra; Schwengeler, Hans Martin; Terentev, Ivan
title: Planet Hunters: Continuing Kepler's Mission
summary: Not long after Kepler's first light, PlanetHunters.org volunteers were observing a number of interesting and unusual exoplanet candidates and more such as the now famous WTF star a.k.a. Tabby's star (KIC 8462852). We plan to continue to assist scientists until mission end, and in that long term spirit propose observation of a handful of both unusual stellar targets and longer-period crossover planet candidates whose stars might yield additional transits. Of special interest are a possible ringed or low mass binary system in EPIC 212684857 where we request short cadence, and several possible hierarchical systems including one with ETV (EPIC 212421319).

coi_names: Garnavich, Peter; Tucker, Brad; Kasen, Dan; Shaya, Ed; Mushotzky, Richard; Margheim, Steve
title: The Kepler Extragalactic Survey (KEGS)
summary: The origins, physical mechanisms, and variety of supernovae (SNe) and other explosive transients remain shrouded in mystery. The continuous 30 minute cadence of K2 will provide critical early time data, probing a window that is inaccessible to traditional ground-based SN surveys. We propose a Large K2 Program to monitor roughly 15,000 bright galaxies in each of Campaigns C17, C18, and C19, which should yield, in total, more than 40 SNe light curves. In the Kepler GO programs, we identified 3 SN Ia (Olling et al. 2015), 2 SN IIP (Garnavich et al. 2016; Tucker et al., submitted), and 1 SN IIn/Ia-csm (Garnavich et al., in prep.). We also discovered several galaxies displaying AGN activity with variability at >0.01% level (Shaya et al 2015). In recent K2 Campaigns, we identified more than 15 SNe, 5 of which were spectroscopically classified. With the lightcurves of unprecedented precision and completeness from this program, we plan to a) determine the types of companions to progenitors of SNe using features in the early breakout (t<4 days) LCs; b) explore the explosion physics of SN, especially SN Ia, using subtle features during their rise (t<10 days); c) improve the calibration of SN Ia as a standard candle for measuring distances, H 0 , and dark energy; and d) also add significantly to the virtually unexplored very low-Eddington regime of AGN. We have coordinated a major, concurrent photometric and spectroscopic follow up campaign, including space-based observatories (HST, Spitzer, Swift) as well as large (e.g. Keck, Gemini, DECam) and small aperture (e.g., SkyMapper, PS1, ATLAS, ZTF, ASAS-SN, LCOGT) ground-based follow-up.

coi_names: Tucker, Brad; Rest, Armin; Shaya, Ed
title: The KEGS Nearby Galaxy Survey: The Final Campaigns
summary: We propose a K2 Program to monitor large, nearby (z < 0.01) galaxies in Campaign 17, 18 and 19. Monitoring of these galaxies will allow us to look for fast (∆t < 10 days) and faint (M > −14) stellar transients. The K2 science mission with its long baseline, high-cadence, power to obtain high precision photometry, and the ability to monitor several targets simultaneously provides a unique opportunity to examine such a broad range of variables and transients.

title: Observations of Neptune’s haze during solar minimum
summary: We propose to use K2 to probe whether the periodic response of Neptune’s atmospheric aerosols to solar FUV and galactic cosmic rays has indeed returned to normal as will be tested by the upcoming solar minimum due during Campaign 19. We will also characterize Neptune’s aerosol haze by the slope of its opposition effect using a 30 min cadence and observations near quadrature and again at minimum solar phase angle during this Campaign.

coi_names: Crossfield, A.; Schlieder, Joshua; Hardegree-Ullman, Kevin; Christiansen, Jessie; Petigura, Erik
title: The K2 M Dwarf Project
summary: The K2 mission provides the opportunity to search for transiting planets orbiting tens of thousands of nearby cool dwarfs. We propose to continue our successful K2 M Dwarf Project (K2-MDP) by acquiring long cadence observations of 8287 cool dwarfs in the campaign 17–19 fields. We anticipate that we will detect 100–200 small planets around late-type stars from the full K2-MDP. Many of these worlds will be smaller than 2R and some might even be habitable. Our observations will increase the number of known M dwarf planetary systems; improve estimates of planet occurrence rates; inform theories of planet formation, evolution, interiors, and atmospheres; and provide new targets for follow-up observations with current and future observatories.

title: Fast Rotation And Flares In The Local Population Of Young K And M Dwarfs
summary: Kepler K2 observations reveal that a significant fraction (>10%) of local M dwarfs with low reduced-proper-motion values are fast-rotators, with periods <4 days. These stars appear to constitute the long sought-after population of young, low-mass stars in the vicinity of the Sun: some are associated with nearby young moving groups (NYMGs). Most of them also show evidence of flaring activity in the long-cadence K2 light curves, and have significant UV excess. The low-cadence (30-minutes) of the K2 observations, however, does not allow the flaring behavior to be examined in detail; high cadence observations of these very active and flaring M dwarfs would reveal much more about the frequency of flaring events, and would allow one to correlate the flaring behavior with the observed changes in the spot patterns on those stars. Campaigns 17-18-19 overlap significantly with earlier campaigns. We find that 79 of the flaring, fast-rotators we discovered in previous campaigns will be available again: 20 M dwarf fast rotators in C17, 41 in C18, and 18 in C19. We propose that these 79 stars be observed in the high-cadence mode, to get a much more detailed look at their flaring behavior.

coi_names: Charbonneau, David; Haywood, Raphaelle; Latham, David; Lopez-Morales, Mercedes; Sasselov, Dimitar; Vanderburg, Andrew
title: Characterizing Small K2 Planets With The HARPS-N Spectrograph
summary:
Follow-up studies of the small planets detected by Kepler have revealed a remarkable diversity of planet densities, indicating that predicting planetary properties from a radius measurement alone could lead to significant errors in our estimate of the frequency of rocky (and possibly habitable) worlds. We propose to study the relationship between the masses, radii, insolation, and metallicities of small planets by targeting moderately bright stars with K2, conducting reconnaissance spectroscopy, and ultimately gathering high-precision radial velocity (RV) measurements with HARPS-N. Our goal is to obtain a mass precision of 15%, the minimum value required to distinguish between compositional models.

This project requires new K2 data for two reasons. First, most transiting small planets detected by Kepler and K2 orbit stars too faint for RV observations, and some of the bright host stars are not amenable to RV observations because of the variability of the host star or the presence of nearby stars. Second, the anticipated number of small planets orbiting quiet, bright stars detected in K2 campaigns to date is small, and the properties of the systems to date do not adequately sample the desired range of planetary and stellar properties.

We propose a ranked list of 12,481 FGKM dwarf stars that are bright enough for RV follow-up and faint enough that they will not require unreasonably large K2 target apertures. We generated this list by first searching for all moderately bright stars that will be on silicon during Campaigns 17, 18, and 19, and then using the available photometry to remove likely giants and constrain the properties of the remaining dwarfs. We also propose to obtain short cadence observations of four planet hosts stars identified in previous K2 campaigns.

coi_names: Metcalfe, Travis
title: Asteroseismology Of Nearby Unevolved Binaries
summary: We propose to observe several well-studied, nearby, main sequence binary systems as fundamental astrophysical calibrators. We specifically target either: 1) systems where oscillations should be detectable in the primary star and the secondary star is of M spectral type, and 2) binaries where both primary and secondary stars should be detectable in solar-like oscillations. These systems are fundamental anchors where binary analysis, astrometry, asteroseismology, and rotation-based stellar characterization methods—particularly for age inference— can be tested, unified, and placed on internally consistent grounds.

title: Getting a Head Start on TESS
summary: The Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) will observe almost all stars below ecliptic latitude of -6 deg and above ecliptic latitude of +6 deg at a cadence of 30 mins or less. We propose to increase the TESS observing baseline by targeting stars with K2 that are visible to TESS. This will allow us to measure exoplanet transit times with baselines of months to years by combining TESS data with K2 data, which will enable us to find planets with long periods, and to measure planet masses using transit timing variations.

coi_names: Pinsonneault, Marc; Buzasi, Derek; Freeman, Ken; Miglio, Andrea; Sharma, Sanjib
title: Galactic archaeology on a grand scale - C17-19
summary: The project will dramatically advance our knowledge about the Milky Way. With major ramifications for the evolution theory of all spiral galaxies, the research will provide a self-consistent picture of the stellar age distribution for tens of thousands of stars in the Milky Way, revealing the first precise timeline for how the Galaxy formed and evolved. The proposal aims to achieve this by observing a sizable number of colour-magnitude selected oscillating red giants to probe the Galaxy using the fossil imprint in its stars far beyond the solar neighborhood. This is a continuing program running since Campaign-0 probing Galactic directions not probed before, taking full advantage of K2’s ‘360-degree view’ along the ecliptic. The high precision and 30-min sampling rate of K2 data are crucial for the project. No other current mission can provide data that will allow us to detect oscillations in large numbers of distant red giants.

title: Neptune and Triton Atmospheric Dynamics
summary: The scientific goals are to determine if the atmosphere/ surface irregular interactions on Neptune can be extrapolated from images taken by K2. If Triton is also in the image then we would also like to investigate the detection of and changes in the N2 atmosphere.
